org.swerverobotics.library

Class ClassFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • ClassFactory

  • public final class ClassFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    ClassFactory provides static methods for instantiating objects within the Swerve Robotics Library. The point here is to separate clients from having to know the actual class names or package structures in which various object implementations are stored; these are often internal, and thus should not be exposed to clients, as they are not stable from release to release.

    • Method Detail

      • createEasyLegacyMotorController

        public static void createEasyLegacyMotorController(OpMode context,
                                                   DcMotor motor1,
                                                   DcMotor motor2)
        If the provided motors are using a legacy motor controller, swaps that controller out and installs an alternate 'EasyLegacyMotorController' DCMotorController implementation for the duration of the OpMode; if the motors are using a modern motor controller, the function has no effect.

        EasyLegacyMotorController is implemented on top of an II2cDeviceClient instance which completely handles all the complexities of read vs write mode switching and the like, allowing the logic inside the controller itself to be extraordinarily simple. In particular, the manual mode switching and loop() counting necessary with the stock controller implementation is not needed. Just call the motor getPosition() or setPower() methods or what have you, and the necessary bookkeeping details will be taken care of.

        EasyLegacyMotorController is not tied to SynchronousOpMode or any other particular OpMode. It can be used, for example, from LinearOpMode, or, indeed, any thread that can tolerate operations that can take tens of milliseconds to run. In SynchronousOpMode, EasyLegacyMotorController is used automatically; in other OpModes, you'll have to manually call createEasyLegacyMotorController(com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode, com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotor, com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotor) yourself.

        This method takes as parameters one or both motors that reside on a given legacy motor controller. If two motors are provided, they must share the same controller, and conversely if two motors reside on a controller then both must be provided. The method creates a new EasyLegacyMotorController and installs it as the controller for the provided motors; the existing controller is disabled. When the current OpMode is complete, the processed is reversed.
        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which this creation is occurring
        motor1 - one of the up-to-two motor controllers which share a legacy motor controller. May be null.
        motor2 - the possibly other motor controller on the same controller. May be null.
        See Also:
        SynchMotorLoopPerf

        parameters - the parameters with which the sensor should be initialized
        Returns:
        the interface to the instantiated sensor object.
        See Also:

      • createAdaFruitBNO055IMU

        public static IBNO055IMU createAdaFruitBNO055IMU(OpMode context,
                                                 I2cDevice i2cDevice,
                                                 IBNO055IMU.Parameters parameters)
        Instantiates a driver object for an AdaFruit BNO055 sensor which resides at the indicated I2cDevice using the provided configuration parameters.

        Features of this sensor include a gyro that does rate integration in hardware to provide robust and accurate angular position indications, and a separation of the output of the accelerometer into gravity and linear-motion-induced components.

        The driver builds on the linear-acceleration information to provide linear velocity and position measurements using integration in software. That said, the built-in accelerometer integration algorithm is quite naive. For a real robot, you'll want to do some investigation and reading and make a better one, whose use you can indicate using parameters.accelerationIntegrationAlgorithm.

        Also, while the out-of-box sensor BNO055 works remarkably well, Bosch describes a one-time calibration process that will make it even better (see Section 3.11). Perform this calibration process in the lab. Once you've got the sensor fully calibrated (or at least the gyro and the accelerometer), extract the configuration state with IBNO055IMU.readCalibrationData(). We suggest that you then incorporate the results as constants in your code, and provide them during OpMode startup in parameters.calibrationData where they will automatically be applied.

        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which this creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the robot controller runtime object representing the sensor
        parameters - the parameters with which the sensor should be initialized
        Returns:
        the interface to the instantiated sensor object. This object also supports the II2cDeviceClientUser interface, which can be useful for debugging.
        See Also:
        createAdaFruitBNO055IMU(OpMode, I2cDevice)

      • createHiTechnicColorSensor

                                                     I2cController controller,
                                                     int port)

        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which the creation is taking place
        controller - the Core Device Legacy Module controller to which the device is attached
        port - the port on the controller that the device attaches to
        Returns:
        a ColorSensor object connected to the device

      • createI2cDevice

                                         int port)
        Creates an II2Device instance on a specific port on an I2cDeviceController
        Parameters:
        i2cController - the controller on which to create the device
        port - the port on the controller to use
        Returns:
        the created II2cDevice instance

      • createI2cDeviceClient

        public static II2cDeviceClient createI2cDeviceClient(OpMode context,
                                                     I2cDevice i2cDevice,
                                                     int i2cAddr8Bit,
                                                     boolean closeOnOpModeStop)
        Create a new II2cDeviceClient on an I2cDevice instance. The client is initially disarmed, and must be armed before use.
        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which the creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the II2cDevice to wrap
        i2cAddr8Bit - the I2C address at which the client is to communicate
        closeOnOpModeStop - if true, then when the OpMode stops, the client will automatically close
        Returns:
        the newly instantiated I2c device client
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.arm()

      • createI2cDeviceClient

        public static II2cDeviceClient createI2cDeviceClient(OpMode context,
                                                     II2cDevice i2cDevice,
                                                     int i2cAddr8Bit,
                                                     boolean closeOnOpModeStop)
        Create a new II2cDeviceClient on an II2cDevice instance. The client is initially disarmed, and must be armed before use.
        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which the creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the II2cDevice to wrap
        i2cAddr8Bit - the I2C address at which the client is to communicate
        closeOnOpModeStop - if true, then when the OpMode stops, the client will automatically close
        Returns:
        the newly instantiated I2c device client
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.arm()

      • createLoopCounter

        public static IOpModeLoopCounter createLoopCounter(OpMode opMode)
        Creates an object that can report the number of times loop() has been called in both Synchronous and Linear OpModes. In the former, this is not necessary, as getLoopCount() may simply be called directly, but this utility object is handy in the latter.
        Parameters:
        opMode - the OpMode in which this loop counter is to report
        Returns:
        the new utility object. Be sure to close() this object before exiting your OpMode
